definition: the School of the Military, one of the Hundred Schools of Thought 諸子百家|诸子百家[zhu1 zi3 bai3 jia1] of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
military strategist in ancient China/military commander/soldier
soldiers/a force/an army/weapons/arms/military/warlike/CL:個|个[ge4]

home/family/(polite) my (sister, uncle etc)/classifier for families or businesses/refers to the philosophical schools of pre-Han China/noun suffix for a specialist in some activity, such as a musician or revolutionary, corresponding to English -ist, -er, -ary or -ian/CL:個|个[ge4]
see 傢伙|家伙[jia1 huo5]
commonplace in military operations (idiom)

sentences.english: Bridges were often points of battle.
sentences.chinese: 桥梁往往是兵家争夺之地。

sentences.english: The Strategist School makes situation stand out; the Legalist School stresses institutionalization.
sentences.chinese: 兵家讲势，法家强调恃人不敢为非的制度化建设。

sentences.english: South Australia has always been a city of Haiphong, the military vital importance.
sentences.chinese: 南澳历来是海防重镇，兵家必争之地。

sentences.english: Mte guardian of the Yangtze River by the throat, has always been contested.
sentences.chinese: 焦山扼守着长江的咽喉，自古是兵家必争之地。

sentences.english: Hallows Eve has been possessed by Hollywood and Walmart.
sentences.chinese: 万圣节前夜也成为好莱坞和沃尔玛的兵家必争之地。

definition: art of war/military strategy and tactics
School of Diplomacy of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC) whose leading advocates were Su Qin 蘇秦|苏秦[Su1 Qin2] and Zhang Yi 張儀|张仪[Zhang4 Yi2]
“Art of War”, one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1], written by Sun Tzu 孫子|孙子[Sun1 zi3]

Legalist School of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC) founded by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] and Li Si 李斯[Li3 Si1], later adopted by Shang Yang 商鞅[Shang1 Yang1] whose reforms helped establish the supremacy of the Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin1 dai4] (221-207 BC)
a book on the art of war

Sun Wu, famous general, strategist and Legalist philosopher, contemporary with Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3] (551-479 BC), author of "The Art of War" 孫子兵法|孙子兵法[Sun1 zi3 Bing1 fa3]/also known as Sun Tzu 孫子|孙子[Sun1 zi3]
Wei Liaozi, one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1], possibly written by Wei Liao 尉繚|尉缭[Wei4 Liao2] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)

Sun Wu, also known as Sun Tzu 孫子|孙子[Sun1 zi3] (c. 500 BC, dates of birth and death uncertain), general, strategist and philosopher of the Spring and Autumn Period (700-475 BC), believed to be the author of the “Art of War” 孫子兵法|孙子兵法[Sun1 zi3 Bing1 fa3], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]
“Methods of Sima”, also called “Sima Rangju’s Art of War”, one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1], written by Sima Rangju 司馬穰苴|司马穰苴[Si1 ma3 Rang2 ju1]
to lead military operations with extraordinary skill
Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
stratagem/strategy/resourcefulness
the Hundred Schools of Thought, the various schools of thought and their exponents during the Spring and Autumn and Warring States Periods (770-220 BC)
Sun Bin's "The Art of War"
military expert/general
Mohist School of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC), founded by the philosopher 墨子[Mo4 zi3]
